issues.text: Whether in calculating the bonus table for the accounting year ending 30-6-1965 the allocation separately made by the Delhi Cloth and General Mills Co. Ltd. towards the Capital and Reserves of the Delhi Cloth Mills and Swatantra Bharat Mills, the two units of the Company, is fair and reasonable? If not, what directions are necessary in this regard?

anchor.surface_text: Whether in calculating the bonus table for the accounting year ending 30-6-1965 the allocation separately made by the Delhi Cloth and General Mills Co. Ltd. towards the Capital and Reserves of the Delhi Cloth Mills and Swatantra Bharat Mills, the two units of the Company, is fair and reasonable ?

issues.text: Whether the workmen of these Mills are entitled to bonus at a rate higher than 6 per cent of the wages for the accounting year ending 30-6-1965? If so, what directions are necessary in this regard?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the workmen of these Mills are entitled to bonus at a rate higher than 6 per cent of the wages for the accounting year ending 30-6-1965 ? If so, what directions are necessary in this regard ?

issues.text: What is the quantum of direct taxes deductible under s. 6 of the Payment of Bonus Act, 1965?

anchor.surface_text: The only point of dispute between the parties to this appeal by special leave from an order of an Industrial Tribunal relates to the quantum of direct taxes deductible under s. 6 of the Payment of Bonus Act, 1965.

issues.text: Whether direct taxes under s.6(c) of the Payment of Bonus Act are to be computed notionally on the income of the establishment alone disregarding other units or as the apportioned actual tax liability of the company?

anchor.surface_text: If the computation of the Management is accepted, then the allocable surplus in terms of s. 2(4) of the Bonus Act is Rs. 22-40 lakhs... According to the appellant direct taxes which have to be deducted for computation of allocable surplus for payment of bonus are Rs. 52-24 lakhs by way of income-tax and Rs. 5-48 lakhs by way of surtax making a total of Rs. 57-72 lakhs, while according to the calculation of the workers direct taxes should be no more than Rs. 10-09 lakhs

holdings.text: the liability under s. 6(c) must be the notional liability of a venture of which the gross profits are known and the prior charges by way of depreciation and development rebate and development allowance have been computed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Computation under Bonus Act independent of actual IT Act assessments; s.7 mandates disregard of losses, exemptions, other incomes; establishment treated fictionally as sole venture.

holdings.text: we hold that the direct taxes under s. 6(c) of the Act were properly quantified by the appellants in their calculation shown in Ex. M-330

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the direct taxes under s. 6  c  of the Act were properly quantified by the appellants

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex. M-330 correctly applies notional method: gross profits Rs.156.09 lakhs minus depreciation Rs.35.83 lakhs and development rebate Rs.2.72 lakhs, balance Rs.117.54 lakhs taxed at 45% income tax Rs.52.24 lakhs plus surtax Rs.5.48 lakhs totalling Rs.57.72 lakhs.

holdings.text: the Tribunal went wrong in assessing that liability on the basis of Ex. M-15

anchor.surface_text: in their calculation shown in Ex. M-330 and the Tribunal went wrong in assessing that liability on the basis of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex. M-15 represents apportioned actual company tax liability under Income-tax Act and Companies Act, irrelevant to notional computation required under ss.6(c) and 7 of Bonus Act for the establishment.

holdings.text: The award will therefore be set aside and modified to provide for bonus being given to the workers at 7.31 per cent of their annual wage bill.

anchor.surface_text: Ex. M-15. The award will therefore be set aside and modified to provide for bonus being given to the workers at

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correct available surplus Rs.37.35 lakhs after proper deductions including direct taxes Rs.57.72 lakhs; allocable surplus 60% Rs.22.40 lakhs on annual wages Rs.306.32 lakhs yields 7.31%.

holdings.text: The Act being a self-contained and self-sufficient Act except in so far as it refers to the other enactments therein mentioned, and in particular the Indian Income-tax Act, it becomes irrelevant to consider the application of the Full Bench formula of the Labour Appellate Tribunal for the computation of bonus before the Act of 1965 was enacted.

anchor.surface_text: The Act being a self-contained and self-sufficient Act except in so far as it refers to the other enactments therein mentioned

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bonus Act 1965 creates complete statutory code superseding prior judicial Full Bench formula; observations in pre-Act cases like Sree Meenakshi Mills and Tulsidas Khimji irrelevant.

holdings.text: where for any accounting year a separate balance-sheet and profit and loss account are prepared and maintained in respect of any such department or undertaking or branch, then, such department or undertaking or branch shall be treated as a separate establishment for the purpose of computation of bonus under this Act for that year, unless such department or undertaking or branch was, immediately before the commencement of that accounting year treated as part of the establishment for the purpose of computation of bonus.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 is the key to the Act in that it fixes the res or the property which is to provide the allocable surplus for the distribution of bonus in terms of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.3 mandates separate treatment for departments/undertakings with separate accounts unless prior practice treated as part of same establishment; here two mills pooled historically.

holdings.text: With respect, we entirely agree with the above observation and in our view no useful purpose will be served by referring to the other observations bearing on a question with which we are not directly concerned.

anchor.surface_text: Strong reliance was placed by learned counsel for the appellant on the decision of this Court in Metal Box Co. v. Workmen

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses Metal Box Co. v. Workmen holding that s.7 requires notional direct tax computation at applicable rates without assessing actual taxable income.

holdings.text: cl. (c) of s. 6 is related to cls. (a) and (b) of the said section.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued at one stage by the respondents that cl. c of s. 6 is number related to cls. a and b of the said section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unrelated interpretation would absurdly tax full gross profits without prior depreciation/development rebate deductions; consistent computation deducts prior charges first.

anchor.surface_text: Strong reliance was placed by learned companynsel for the appel- lant on the decision of this Court in Metal Box Co. v. Work- men 1 . Counsel for the respondents made valiant efforts to persuade us to hold that many of the observations therein were obiter

precedents.cited_proposition: computation of direct taxes under s.6(c) of the Payment of Bonus Act as notional liability at applicable rates without assessing actual taxable income
precedents.cited_holding: What s. 7 really means is that the Tribunal has to compute the direct taxes at the rates at which the income, gains and profits of the employer are taxed under the Income Tax Act and other such Acts during the accounting year in question. That is the reason why S. 6 c  has the words is liable, for and the words income, gains and profits. These words do not, however, mean that the Tribunal while computing direct taxes as a prior charge has to assess the actual taxable income and the taxes thereon.

precedents.citation: Mls. Alloy Steel Project v. The Workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: In Mls. Alloy Steel Project v. The Workmen 1  where the project was owned, controlled and managed by a Government Company, viz., Messrs Hindustan Steel Ltd., and separate balance sheet and profit and loss accounts of the undertaking were maintained,

precedents.case_name: Alloy Steel Project v The Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: separate balance sheet and profit and loss accounts make a department or undertaking a separate establishment under s.3 proviso of Payment of Bonus Act despite common ownership
precedents.cited_holding: the claim of the workmen that the project was a part of the Hindustan Steel Ltd. should be upheld and its employees placed on the same footing as the other employees of the steel company was rejected

justification_sets.label: Payment of Bonus Act Section 6 support

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the direct taxes under s. 6  c  of the Act were properly quantified by the appellants in their calculation shown in Ex. M-330 and the Tribunal went wrong in assessing that liability on the basis of Ex. M-15. The award will therefore be set aside and modified to provide for bonus being given to the workers at 7.31 per

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; tribunal award set aside and modified to direct payment of 10% bonus on wages for the accounting year ending 30-6-1965
directions: The Advocate for the appellant renewed the offer to pay ten per cent of the wages of the employees as bonus for the relevant year
The offer was accepted on behalf of the employees by their Advocates
The award will, accordingly, stand modified, and the provision of ten per cent of wages as bonus be inserted therein
The payment of bonus will be made before Diwali, 1971
There will be no liability to pay interest

Payment of Bonus Act Section 4 on computation of gross profits referring to schedules directly addresses the issue concerning allocations in calculating the bonus table.

The Payment of Bonus Act Third Schedule (c17) addresses the issue (i1) of whether specific allocations made by the company towards capital in bonus calculation for the accounting year ending 30-6-1965 are to be considered, as the Third Schedule governs treatment of such allocations in allocable surplus computation under the Act.
